guide.introduction: I will teach you the right way to convert cheap mirrors into top quality front surface mirrors. The process is simple to use and the final results are great. Please note that this technique is so simple, photographs are not required.
guide.introduction_rendered:
I will teach you the right way to convert cheap mirrors into top quality front surface mirrors. The process is simple to use and the final results are great. Please note that this technique is so simple, photographs are not required.

Tools
  • A container of paint stripper
  • A conventional back surface mirror
  • A few standard business cards or other thin cardboard stock
  • A gallon of distilled water
  • A soft brush to spread the stripper
  • A spray bottle filled with soapy, distilled water
  • A spray bottle filled with warm distilled water
  • Cotton balls
  • Methanol Alcohol (optional, see Text)
  • Pure Acetone (optional, see text)
  • Several plastic tubs for holding materials and cleaning glass
  • Soap or detergent. I suggest Green Soap from the drugstore. This soap is very mild, it does not contain any fragrances and it is non-abrasive.
  • Some newspapers, stripper resistant gloves and eye protection to protect both the work surface and the worker

lines.text: Before you begin, make sure that you read and understand any safety information and handling instructions provided by the manufacturer. Paint strippers are quite caustic, so handle paint stripper with care. I have tried a variety of commercial paint strippers and they all work well in this application. I like automotive paint stripper in an aerosol can, but I also use non-aerosol strippers if they are on sale at the local Home Center. Before you begin, prepare your work surface. I use newspapers, but anything that can protect your work surface from the action of the stripper is fine.
lines.text_raw: Before you begin, make sure that you read and understand any safety information and handling instructions provided by the manufacturer. Paint strippers are quite caustic, so handle paint stripper with care. I have tried a variety of commercial paint strippers and they all work well in this application. I like automotive paint stripper in an aerosol can, but I also use non-aerosol strippers if they are on sale at the local Home Center. Before you begin, prepare your work surface. I use newspapers, but anything that can protect your work surface from the action of the stripper is fine.

lines.text: I usually place the mirror in a plastic tub lined with newspaper. This makes clean up a snap. I might suggest that before you begin, mix a little detergent and warm distilled water and fill a cheap plastic tub. This will be your primary rinse station.
lines.text_raw: I usually place the mirror in a plastic tub lined with newspaper. This makes clean up a snap. I might suggest that before you begin, mix a little detergent and warm distilled water and fill a cheap plastic tub. This will be your primary rinse station.

lines.text: Place the mirrored glass on your work surface liberally coat the painted backing with paint stripper. Make sure you cover the entire painted backing with stripper. Once you apply the stripper, wait for the reaction to start. At first, nothing will appear to happen. Then all of a sudden, the painted backing will bubble and crack and the painted layer will puff up. The reaction happens rapidly, leaving you with a uniform crackled appearance.
lines.text_raw: Place the mirrored glass on your work surface liberally coat the painted backing with paint stripper. Make sure you cover the entire painted backing with stripper. Once you apply the stripper, wait for the reaction to start. At first, nothing will appear to happen. Then all of a sudden, the painted backing will bubble and crack and the painted layer will puff up. The reaction happens rapidly, leaving you with a uniform crackled appearance.

lines.text: Carefully slip the corner of a business card between the painted layer and the mirrored glass and lift the painted backing layer free from the mirror. In most cases, you can lift the entire painted backing free, leaving almost no residue remaining on the silver coating.
lines.text_raw: Carefully slip the corner of a business card between the painted layer and the mirrored glass and lift the painted backing layer free from the mirror. In most cases, you can lift the entire painted backing free, leaving almost no residue remaining on the silver coating.

lines.text: Spray the glass liberally using your detergent and water filled spray bottle. The goal is to remove the majority of paint stripper before you place the glass in the first cleaning tub. Spray the edges, the front and back of the glass.
lines.text_raw: Spray the glass liberally using your detergent and water filled spray bottle. The goal is to remove the majority of paint stripper before you place the glass in the first cleaning tub. Spray the edges, the front and back of the glass.

lines.text: Next, place the mirror into the tub of soapy water, and carefully remove any residual stripper from the glass using a few cotton balls. When you clean the mirrored layer, be very careful. The silver layer is exceedingly thin. In fact, if you hold the stripped glass up to the light, the glass will have a smoky appearance. This “smoke” is the silver layer that forms the mirror.
lines.text_raw: Next, place the mirror into the tub of soapy water, and carefully remove any residual stripper from the glass using a few cotton balls. When you clean the mirrored layer, be very careful. The silver layer is exceedingly thin. In fact, if you hold the stripped glass up to the light, the glass will have a smoky appearance. This “smoke” is the silver layer that forms the mirror.

lines.text: Always work under water to avoid scratches. Use a light touch and do not scrub the mirrored coating. Do not worry if you see fine scratches. They will not (generally) cause a problem unless they are big. You can tell if scratches will be a problem by looking at the front of the mirror after it is clean and dry.  Place the mirror against a black background and look at the surface of the coating. In most cases, you should not see too many scratches.

They will not (generally) cause a problem unless they are big. You can tell if scratches will be a problem by looking at the front of the mirror after it is clean and dry.  Place the mirror against a black background and look at the surface of the coating. In most cases, you should not see too many scratches.

lines.text: If you see traces of the copper layer, you can remove it using a cotton ball and a very light touch during the cleaning stage. I use mirrored wall ties for my mirror source and I seldom see the copper layer; it comes off with the stripper.
lines.text_raw: If you see traces of the copper layer, you can remove it using a cotton ball and a very light touch during the cleaning stage. I use mirrored wall ties for my mirror source and I seldom see the copper layer; it comes off with the stripper.

lines.text: copper layer; it comes off with the stripper.  After cleaning, place the glass in a tub of distilled water and carefully agitate the glass. Agitate for at least 30 seconds, then lift the glass and let it drain.

lines.text: Now, place the glass into a container of methanol alcohol and agitate for at least 15 seconds. Lift the mirror and let it drain. The alcohol will help the drying process and greatly reduce the tendency for water spots to form. Methanol is also part of the immersion cleaning process described later.

The alcohol will help the drying process and greatly reduce the tendency for water spots to form. Methanol is also part of the immersion cleaning process described later.

lines.text: Finally, inspect your mirror for obvious issues and problems. Should you find a serious flaw, simply make another mirror.

lines.text: You can clean smaller mirrors using a variety of techniques. The Immersion Cleaning Technique is the best technique I have found for cleaning delicate optical surfaces.  1. Place some lens cleaning tissue in the bottom of a small dish. I prefer glass. Make sure the dish is large enough to hold the mirrored glass
lines.text_raw: You can clean smaller mirrors using a variety of techniques. The Immersion Cleaning Technique is the best technique I have found for cleaning delicate optical surfaces.  1. Place some lens cleaning tissue in the bottom of a small dish. I prefer glass. Make sure the dish is large enough to hold the mirrored glass

lines.text: 2. Fill the dish with methanol alcohol and place your mirror in this dish. Carefully wipe (while immersed) the silver surface using cotton balls. After you wipe down the mirror, agitate the dish for fifteen seconds
lines.text_raw: 2. Fill the dish with methanol alcohol and place your mirror in this dish. Carefully wipe (while immersed) the silver surface using cotton balls. After you wipe down the mirror, agitate the dish for fifteen seconds

lines.text: 3. Remove the mirror and allow it to drain for a few moments and repeat the above steps using Acetone rather than Methanol Alcohol
lines.text_raw: 3. Remove the mirror and allow it to drain for a few moments and repeat the above steps using Acetone rather than Methanol Alcohol

lines.text: 4. Finally, remove the mirror from the Acetone, let it drain for a few moments and blow it dry.
lines.text_raw: 4. Finally, remove the mirror from the Acetone, let it drain for a few moments and blow it dry.

lines.text: When it comes to selecting glass mirrors to be converted, I prefer mirrored wall tiles from the local Home Center. They strip cleanly and I encounter very few problems like scratches. For smaller pre-cut mirrors, try your local craft store. You can find many different mirror shapes and sizes. In addition, pre-cut craft mirrors seem to suffer fewer problems like scratches. This process is suitable for most of your mirror making needs. The benefit
